detaileddescription.para: These macros generate both an enum and an array of strings, these are used as part of the tokenizer to parse the names of the keywords out of the BASIC program without having to remember to match up a string and its token enum value in two places. It is also used for error reporting.

briefdescription.para: All tokens recognised by the interpreter. Note that built in function names are NOT tokens, they are parsed like user functions, just with a hard coded handler instead of redirecting into the user program.

detaileddescription.para: The #define below builds an enum, and can also build an array of strings of the names in the enum, which is built and used within ubasic.c for tokenization.

memberdef.type: *brief Initialise tokenizer **param program program text *param ctx context *void
memberdef.definition: * brief Initialise tokenizer* * param program program text* param ctx context* void tokenizer_init
memberdef.name: tokenizer_init

briefdescription.para: Get integer number as next token (do not advance the pointer)
Get real number as next token (do not advance the pointer)
Get a variable name as next token (do not advance the pointer)
Get a string constant as the next token (do not advance the pointer)

simplesect.para: true if succesfully found a string constant

briefdescription.para: Returns true if the program is finished (does not advance the pointer)

simplesect.para: int true if the program has finished

briefdescription.para: display an error to the terminal and end the program

simplesect.para: If the program is running an EVAL, the error is printed but the program is not ended, instead ERROR$ and ERROR are set.

briefdescription.para: Get the next token (advances the pointer past the end of the token)
Check if a decimal number is at the current program pointer. (does not advance the pointer)

simplesect.para: true if pointer points at a decimal number

detaileddescription.para: BBC BASIC interpreter, Retro Rocket OS Project (C) Craig Edwards 2012. loosely based on uBASIC (Copyright (c) 2006, Adam Dunkels, All rights reserved).
